title: Why the S&P 500 may be headed almost 20% lower even without a recession
text:
Before thinking about the S&P 500 (^GSPC) reaching 3,500 sometime in early 2020, start pondering the chances of the S&P 500 hitting 2,500, says one investing veteran.

“I think the S&P 500 will trade at 2,500 before it trades at 3,500,” SMH Global CEO George Ball said on Yahoo Finance’s The First Trade. “I am a bull by nature, but there is a fatigue factor and there is a litany of risk factors that are fairly daunting. They say markets often climb a wall of worry, and there is a wall of worry. At some point those worries — such as the Fed being tired on rate cuts and trade tensions — then investors will shift their paradigm and become more cautious.”

Others on Wall Street share Ball’s reservation on the now red-hot markets.

“None of these moves [in the market] can be seen as anything but a bounce from oversold conditions…and we’re going to have to see more upside follow-through before one could say with any real confidence that these moves are anything more than technical ones,” says Miller Tabak chief strategist Matt Maley. “Therefore, despite all the hoopla around the new high in the S&P 500 yesterday, nobody can realistically make ANY definitive conclusions from the recent action in any of the markets.”

If Ball’s call were to happen — a big if when compared against a market ripping higher to new records this month — it would represent about a 20% haircut from current levels. Something along the lines of the Federal Reserve signaling at one of its two remaining meetings this year it’s done cutting interest rates would have to occur to truly spook the bulls. Or, the market grows completely impatient with the Trump administration’s timeline on delivering phase two of its trade deal with China.

(AP Photo/Richard Drew, File) More

Or hey, the president gets impeached — that’s a factor not priced into the markets at all and largely ignored as a risk by many Wall Street pros Yahoo Finance has chatted up. So, as Ball correctly points out, there are logical catalysts out there that could nail stocks.

But until then, the market could very well stay on autopilot into 2020.

The S&P 500 is enjoying a record-setting week, spurred by hopes for another interest rate cut from the Fed this week and a spate of better than expected third quarter earnings reports. Year-to-date, the Nasdaq Composite is up roughly 24%, the S&P 500 has gained 21% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) has tacked on 16%.

“I am not sure we go all the way down to S&P 500 2,500. We continue to see the trend move higher — 3,500 and 2,500 seem like extremes to me. I do think we will trend higher, and we do not see a recession coming,” thinks Crossmark Global Investments chief markets strategist Victoria Fernandez.

Brian Sozzi is an editor-at-large and co-anchor of The First Trade at Yahoo Finance. Follow him on Twitter @BrianSozzi

description: Stocks are back to hitting new records daily. But here is why that may not last for long.
